query: 给出参考文献时，请忠实给出原文档名，不要翻译成中文，也不要把relation等误当作文档名。如何加强和优化中非多层次国际合作机制，实现跨境疫情信息即时共享、资源有效整合和公共卫生能力全面提升，增强非洲公共卫生体系的生物安全应对能力和整体韧性？

entities.description: A grouping of informational items including press releases, briefs, and advisories related to health emergency response and preparedness in Africa.
Various regional, continental, and global organizations working in partnership to support pathogen genomics and public health responses in Africa.
Communication and public information units at both Africa CDC and APHF coordinate outreach and media engagement to support partnership and public health initiatives.
Periodic publication by Africa CDC providing updates and overviews on health emergencies and outbreak responses in Africa between specified dates.

entities.entity: Memorandum of Cooperation to Promote Public Health Partnership
entities.description: A formal agreement signed in March 2022 between Africa CDC and the U.S. government outlining objectives for collaboration in public health to strengthen systems and outcomes in Africa.

Cross-border collaboration refers to cooperative efforts between neighboring African Union member states for mpox preparedness and response including data sharing, joint planning, and resource distribution.

Africa CDC Weekly Briefs are a series of recurring weekly briefing documents published by the Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) that provide timely updates on health issues, disease surveillance, and outbreak response efforts across the African continent. These briefs serve as important situational updates on public health emergencies, ongoing strategies, and efforts such as outbreak responses and diagnostic decentralization. Specific editions of the briefs referenced include those dated 30 June–6 July 2025, 7–13 July 2025, and 14–20 July 2025, reflecting the continuous commitment of Africa CDC to inform and support health stakeholders with up-to-date information on the continent's public health landscape.

The New Public Health Order is a comprehensive thematic framework and strategic approach aimed at advancing coordinated global and regional public health responses, particularly in Africa. It focuses on strengthening pandemic prevention, preparedness, and response, while emphasizing the development of a resilient health workforce and robust public health systems. Central to the New Public Health Order are principles of respectful partnership and enhanced cooperation between stakeholders, as highlighted in the Memorandum of Understanding between Africa CDC and France. The framework also addresses critical priority areas including One Health, antimicrobial resistance (AMR), digital health, and climate and health initiatives, reflecting an evolving approach to health cooperation and strategic reforms designed to improve health outcomes both regionally and globally.
Regular published updates by Africa CDC that provide information on ongoing public health topics and activities across Africa.

Regional Emergency Hubs comprise three WHO-established centers in Africa (Dakar, Nairobi, Pretoria) created to improve rapid and effective responses to health emergencies, each with specialized functions including supply chain, medical personnel development, research, and genomic surveillance.

Information Sharing refers to the exchange of data and updates on potential health threats and preparedness and response measures among countries and organizations to strengthen disease control and public health security.

Health Security encompasses the systems, policies, efforts, and investments aimed at protecting populations from health threats by preventing, detecting, and responding to infectious disease threats, epidemics, and other health emergencies globally. It involves the capacity of health systems to prepare for, respond to, and recover from health emergencies, which relies on a sufficiently resourced health workforce. In the context of Africa, the Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) between Africa CDC and the European Union focuses on improving health security across the continent by enhancing disease surveillance, emergency response, and building more robust public health systems. The partnership aims to strengthen Africa CDC’s capacity to ensure effective health security measures throughout Africa, safeguarding populations against current and future health threats.

The Africa CDC and UNICEF Partnership Framework Agreement, started in 2022 and extended to 2027, formalizes collaboration on public health emergency preparedness, immunisation system strengthening, and procurement and supply chain enhancement.

entities.entity: Media Advisory Weekly Special Press Briefing on Health Emergencies in Africa
entities.description: Regular media advisory event for weekly special press briefings on health emergencies in Africa.

entities.entity: Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention
entities.description: The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) is a continental autonomous public health agency and specialized technical institution of the African Union. It is dedicated to supporting Member States across Africa in strengthening health systems by improving disease surveillance, emergency response, prevention, and control of diseases. Africa CDC focuses on enhancing the continent's capacity to detect, prevent, and respond to health emergencies, including combating deadly diseases such as drug-resistant infections and pandemics. Additionally, the agency plays a key role in communication and information dissemination related to health emergencies and outbreak response. Africa CDC also leads the African Union's public health initiatives, including pandemic prevention, preparedness, and response, aiming to build resilient health systems throughout Africa.<SEP>The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention is a continental public health agency collaborating closely with WHO and the regional emergency hubs to strengthen emergency preparedness and health systems in Africa.

A specific weekly briefing published by Africa CDC providing updates on health emergencies and related activities for the week of 14–20 July 2025.<SEP>A weekly briefing report issued by Africa CDC detailing health emergency developments and updates for the week of 14 – 20 July 2025.

Africa CDC (Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention) is the specialized, continental autonomous public health agency of the African Union dedicated to strengthening health institutions and capacities across Africa. Its primary mission is to enhance disease surveillance, outbreak response, and emergency preparedness to detect, prevent, control, and manage health threats throughout the continent. As a leading public health institution in Africa, Africa CDC plays a central role in building health security and coordinating regional responses to infectious disease epidemics, including mpox, by collaborating closely with African governments and global partners such as the World Health Organization (WHO), the European Union, and Gavi.

Africa CDC actively co-leads initiatives like the Joint Emergency Preparedness and Response Action Plan (JEAP) to address disease outbreaks and public health emergencies, while providing technical support, capacity building, and epidemic response coordination. The agency emphasizes genomic surveillance strategies as part of its comprehensive approach to managing public health challenges and strengthening health systems continent-wide.

In addition to its role in disease control, Africa CDC leads and supports critical vaccine manufacturing initiatives, including the African Vaccine Manufacturing Alliance (AVMA), with the goal of increasing local production to meet 60% of Africa’s demand for vaccines, medicines, and diagnostics by 2040. The agency promotes sustainable vaccine development, regulatory harmonization, decentralization of diagnostics, and localization of health product manufacturing to build resilient and self-sufficient health systems.

Operating under the African Union's Agenda 2063 and guided by a strategic plan for 2023-2027, Africa CDC strives to enhance health sovereignty, improve health outcomes, strengthen emergency response capabilities, and foster knowledge-sharing and institutional strengthening across African countries. Through these efforts, Africa CDC empowers Africa’s health security and advances the continent’s ability to manage current and future public health threats effectively.

entities.entity: Partnership for Public Health Emergencies Preparedness & Response
entities.description: A collaborative partnership focused on responding to public health emergencies in Africa, seeking 1 billion USD funding to improve preparedness, detection, and response to emergencies triggered by climate change and conflict-related disasters.

entities.entity: Public Health Emergency Preparedness and Response
entities.description: The activities and capabilities focused on anticipating, preparing for, and effectively managing public health emergencies in Africa.
Monitoring and analysis of disease-causing agents to detect emerging infections early, guide vaccine development and public health responses, strengthened under the Africa CDC and CEPI partnership.

The World Health Organization (WHO) is a specialized agency of the United Nations responsible for international public health. It collaborates closely with various partners, including the Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC), the African Union, and European Union partners, to support and strengthen health systems and improve access to medicines in Africa. The WHO provides guidance under the International Health Regulations and actively supports responses to outbreaks such as mpox in Africa. Additionally, through initiatives like the Joint Emergency Action Plan (JEAP), the WHO works to enhance emergency preparedness and response capabilities across the African continent.

entities.entity: Africa Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC)
entities.description: Africa CDC is the continental public health agency of the African Union mandated to support African member states in building robust health systems, safeguarding health security, and accelerating universal health coverage. It focuses on outbreak and pandemic prevention, health systems strengthening, and local manufacturing of health commodities including vaccines.
The Africa CDC Website is the online platform providing information on Africa CDC activities, resources, and communications.

A thematic focus area emphasizing strengthening surveillance, genomic sequencing, supply stockpiling, and rapid deployment of responders to improve Africa’s ability to manage public health emergencies.<SEP>Emergency Response and Preparedness is a broad and strategic theme encompassing activities, strategies, and measures aimed at responding to and preparing for public health emergencies, particularly health crises and outbreaks such as Mpox in Africa. It involves the rapid and effective mobilization of resources and capacities for Mpox surveillance, containment, and mitigation across the continent. This focus area prioritizes building capacity for timely and efficient response mechanisms, as highlighted in the Joint Action Plan and efforts led by Africa CDC. Overall, Emergency Response and Preparedness addresses the comprehensive and coordinated actions required to manage public health emergencies effectively throughout Africa.

entities.entity: Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC)
entities.description: Africa CDC is a continental public health agency mandated to address significant health threats in Africa, including coordinating epidemic responses by mobilizing African leaders, governments, and agencies. It declared mpox a Public Health Emergency of Continental Security (PHECS) on August 13, 2024.<SEP>Continental public health agency leading efforts to scale up local vaccine manufacturing in Africa. It hosted a High-Level meeting during the 77th World Health Assembly, led vaccine landscape analysis in partnership with Clinton Health Access Initiative and PATH, and directs initiatives like the African Pooled Procurement Mechanism for improving access and manufacturing.<SEP>The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) is a continental autonomous public health agency of the African Union. It supports member states in strengthening health systems, improving disease surveillance, emergency response, and disease prevention and control across Africa. Africa CDC leads efforts to enhance epidemic and pandemic preparedness and is responsible for strengthening public health institutions and partnerships throughout the continent. The agency focuses on detecting and responding quickly and effectively to disease threats and outbreaks by implementing data-driven interventions and programs.

A series of weekly reports and communication briefs issued by Africa CDC which offer updates on health conditions, emergencies, and strategic responses in Africa.<SEP>The Africa CDC Weekly Brief is a recurrent publication that provides updates on health-related developments, strategies, and implementation plans across the continent."|>"Africa CDC Weekly Brief | 14 – 20 July 2025...7 – 13 July 2025...30 June-6 July 2025

entities.description: A WHO African regional strategy covering integrated disease surveillance and response for the period 2020-2030 to improve epidemic detection and health emergency management including for mpox.

entities.description: Weekly briefing by Africa CDC providing updates on health emergencies from 30 June to 6 July 2025.<SEP>Weekly health status and genomic surveillance report from Africa CDC for the period 30 June to 6 July 2025.

The African Continent is the geographic focus of the health partnerships and initiatives described, encompassing diverse regions and countries collectively engaged to enhance health sovereignty, pandemic preparedness, and health system resilience."|>"Foundations of our cooperation with the African continent... to build resilient health systems... support global health internationally

entities.entity: Third International Conference on Public Health in Africa
entities.description: An international conference focused on public health in Africa where key statements and collaborations, such as the announcement of the Joint Action Plan between Africa CDC and the United States government, take place.

This group consists of international partners such as WHO, Africa CDC, UNICEF, US CDC, USAID, CEPI, Wellcome Trust, and GAVI, providing both technical expertise and financial support for mpox epidemic response and preparedness in African countries.
A priority area in the Africa CDC strategy and collaborative Agreement, focusing on improving institutional capacity and the health workforce across African Union Member States.

Emergency preparedness and response involves the surveillance, rapid detection, supply stockpiling, and deployment of first responders to manage disease outbreaks and health emergencies effectively.<SEP>Preparedness and response mechanisms for public health emergencies are a critical focus of the partnership, aiming to enable rapid, coordinated actions to manage outbreaks and health crises across Africa.

The Media Advisory is a communication tool used primarily by Africa CDC to inform media representatives and the public about upcoming events, briefings, or important developments related to health emergencies and disease surveillance in Africa. It serves as a notice indicating scheduled communications or announcements, including weekly special press briefings, aimed at keeping the media and public informed about health-related issues and initiatives on the continent.

entities.entity: Communication and Public Information Directorate, Africa CDC
entities.description: The Communication and Public Information Directorate of Africa CDC manages communication outreach and public information dissemination related to Africa CDC activities and initiatives."|>"Media inquiry: Communication and Public Information Directorate | Africa CDC | Email: Communications@africacdc.org
Organizations and entities that function as partners in implementing genomic surveillance projects and outbreak response activities across Africa.

entities.entity: Weekly Special Press Briefing on Health Emergencies in Africa
entities.description: The Weekly Special Press Briefing on Health Emergencies in Africa is a recurring, regularly scheduled media event organized by the Africa CDC. It serves as a platform to communicate updates, information, and responses related to health emergencies and outbreak situations across the African continent. This briefing provides timely and coordinated information to keep the public and stakeholders informed about ongoing health threats and the efforts being undertaken to address them.<SEP>This weekly briefing informs on health emergencies in Africa providing updates and coordination information consequential to epidemic or pandemic threats."|>"Weekly Special Press Briefing on Health Emergencies in Africa

The European Commission acts within the EU framework to implement strategic health partnerships with Africa, providing funding such as TEI MAV+ for African Medicines Agency advancement, and collaborating in launching health security initiatives and programs like SafeBirth Africa.<SEP>The European Commission is the executive branch of the EU, responsible for proposing legislation and implementing decisions, leading the EU delegation and coordinating follow-ups on the health partnership.
National and regional governments across African countries engaged in collaborations to support the implementation of pathogen genomic surveillance and outbreak response.

entities.entity: Africa CDCs New Public Health Order
entities.description: An existing framework by Africa CDC forming part of the foundation for the JEAP, aimed at strengthening health security across Africa.

The World Health Organization (WHO) is an international public health agency and a global health authority that collaborates closely with Africa CDC, the African Health Regulatory Observatory (AHRO), and other partners to enhance emergency preparedness, disease classification, and health systems strengthening plans across Africa. WHO provides technical support, facilitates information exchange, and coordinates efforts for mpox preparedness and response throughout the continent. Additionally, WHO administers the WHO prequalification process, which serves as a global standard to assure the quality and efficacy of vaccines and health products for procurement agencies worldwide.<SEP>The World Health Organization (WHO) is an international public health agency leading efforts to eliminate visceral leishmaniasis (VL) as a public health problem in eastern Africa through launching new frameworks and coordinating regional health policies.

The United Nations Children's Fund is the first partner to join the JEAP partnership, contributing to efforts to transform health security on the African continent.<SEP>UNICEF is a global organization and the United Nations agency dedicated to children's welfare, operating in over 190 countries and territories. It focuses on supporting disadvantaged children worldwide through efforts related to child rights, health, immunization, community health programs, humanitarian action, and supply operations. In addition to its broad mission, UNICEF actively contributes to specific health initiatives such as supporting mpox response efforts in Africa alongside other international partners. The organization also plays a key role as an implementing partner in enhancing vaccine storage by procuring and delivering cold chain equipment in African Union Member States. Through these comprehensive activities, UNICEF strives to build a better world for all children.<SEP>UNICEF is an international organization working as a partner with WHO and others to support the malaria vaccine rollout efforts in African countries through coordination and resource mobilization.

APHF is an organization established to mobilize resources and investments for critical African public health activities in support of Africa CDC and the African Union’s New Public Health Order, focusing on resource mobilisation, grants management, advocacy, private sector engagement, and public health data analysis.<SEP>APHF is an organization partnering with Africa CDC to mobilize resources and support public health laboratory systems and initiatives in Africa, specifically to advance pathogen genomics and pandemic preparedness.

WHO Africa is the Regional Office for Africa of the World Health Organization, dedicated to supporting African countries in immunization, disease prevention, and pandemic preparedness.<SEP>WHO Africa refers to the World Health Organization's Regional Office for Africa responsible for health initiatives and programs across the continent, including the malaria vaccine rollout.

The United Kingdom is a sovereign country in Europe making significant financial commitments towards global health, focusing on research, development, and tackling health challenges worldwide, particularly in Africa.

entities.entity: Ministers of Health of Angola, Benin, Burundi, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo, Gabon, Ghana, Liberia, Nigeria, Uganda
entities.description: The Ministers of Health from multiple African countries including Angola, Benin, Burundi, Cameroon, Central African Republic, Congo, Democratic Republic of Congo, Gabon, Ghana, Liberia, Nigeria, and Uganda, who convened in a high-level meeting in Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo, on 13 April 2024 to address the mpox outbreak.

The European Union (EU) is a political and economic union of member states in Europe, leading the European delegation in strategic health partnerships with Africa to strengthen global and African health.<SEP>The European Union is a political and economic union of member states in Europe that co-funded Africa CDC’s genomic surveillance and molecular diagnostics projects.<SEP>The European Union is a supranational organization committed to global health improvement through partnerships with African counterparts, focusing on pandemic agreements, health system strengthening, funding programs, and health security initiatives under the AU-EU Health partnership framework.

The United States government is collaborating with Africa CDC to advance a shared vision for strengthening public health systems and improving health outcomes in Africa through a Joint Action Plan that includes institutional strengthening, expert exchanges, and emergency preparedness.
The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (US CDC) is a US federal health agency providing technical and financial support to assist African countries' responses to mpox outbreaks.
Private sector entities collaborating with Africa CDC and partners in public health initiatives including diagnostics and pathogen genomics.

The United Kingdom government has committed significant financial resources and partnerships aimed at advancing global health, supporting disease control and vaccine development initiatives, particularly in Africa and low- and middle-income countries.

The European Union Commission is the executive branch of the European Union responsible for proposing legislation, implementing decisions, and managing day-to-day EU business, and here it partners with Africa CDC to support access to health products and local manufacturing in Africa.

The COVID-19 pandemic exposed vulnerabilities in healthcare systems and medical supply chains globally, highlighting the need for strengthening health infrastructure.<SEP>The COVID-19 pandemic was a global health crisis that prompted WHO Africa to develop decentralized emergency response systems and contributed to establishing these regional emergency hubs.

Sierra Leone is among the five African Union Member States receiving state-of-the-art cold chain equipment to strengthen healthcare systems and vaccine delivery.<SEP>Sierra Leone is an African country involved in regional health emergency and medical supply efforts.
Immunisation is a public health intervention aimed at preventing disease through vaccination. It is a key focus area in the partnership to increase vaccination coverage among children in Africa.
France is a country in Europe that collaborates with Africa CDC to strengthen public health systems in Africa through a memorandum of understanding and various support initiatives.
The African Union is a continental union consisting of 55 member states in Africa engaged as partners in health initiatives including Africa CDC’s genomic surveillance projects.
Standards and procedures ensuring safety in vaccine development, clinical trials, manufacturing, and deployment, enhanced through the Africa CDC and CEPI partnership to maintain trust and efficacy.
Occurrences of epidemics or pandemics involving emerging infectious diseases in Africa that Africa CDC and CEPI aim to prevent and respond to through enhanced preparedness and vaccine initiatives.

relations.description: Africa CDC and WHO collaborate closely to strengthen health emergency preparedness and response in Africa. They provide technical support through mechanisms established at multiple levels, including headquarters, regional centres, and country offices, specifically for the mpox response. Together, they have launched the Joint Emergency Preparedness and Response Action Plan (JEAP), a strategic partnership aimed at enhancing health systems and combating disease outbreaks across the continent. This initiative reflects their joint commitment to improving Africa's capacity to manage health emergencies effectively.

Africa CDC and WHO Launch Joint Emergency Preparedness and Response Action Plan (JEAP) to Strengthen Health Systems and Combat Disease Outbreaks in Africa
Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) and World Health Organization (WHO) are pleased to announce the launch of a Joint Emergency Preparedness and Response Action Plan (JEAP).

It supports continent-wide public health initiatives by coordinating responses to infectious diseases, including mpox, within the framework of the African Union's health security statutes and policies. As a technical institution, Africa CDC plays a vital role in advancing health systems and enhancing pandemic preparedness across Africa, working under the broader organizational and strategic framework of the African Union.

Africa CDC and Africa Public Health Foundation Forge Strategic Partnership to Strengthen Health Systems – Africa CDC
Skip to content
Email:
communications@africacdc.org
Search
Search
News
/
Press Releases
Africa CDC and Africa Public Health Foundation Forge Strategic Partnership to Strengthen Health Systems
Nairobi, Kenya. July 25, 2024
– The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) and Africa Public Health Foundation (APHF) have signed an agreement to support strengthening health systems in Africa Union Member States.
APHF was established to enable investments in public health activities that support Africa CDC’s goals and objectives across the continent. It’s main operational vectors include resource mobilisation, grants management, advocacy for improved policies, private sector engagement and contributing to the analysis of public health data.
H.E. Dr. Jean Kaseya, Director General of Africa CDC, remarked, “Africa CDC’s strategic plan 2023-2027 is ambitious, aiming to achieve significant outcomes for the continent. The Africa Public Health Foundation is pivotal in facilitating resource mobilisation for Africa CDC, enhancing public health systems across African Union Member States, and supporting the implementation of The New Public Health Order.”
APHF supports the Africa CDC New Public Health Order in its mission to build a healthier and more prosperous Africa.
Dr. Bernard Haufiku, APHF Governing Council Chair and Founder, states, “I am excited about this special day as we have been looking forward to this momentous occasion on which we sign the Agreement between APHF and Africa CDC. Our strategic partnership has benefited the continent through resource mobilisation to respond to the COVID-19 pandemic, the Ebola, Marburg, and Cholera outbreaks, and related interventions. I am grateful to Africa CDC for the support over the years since we started working in 2020 and the great work we have done together.”
The Agreement outlines the collaboration modalities between the two institutions, with the priority areas articulated in the Africa CDC strategy as a reference. These include strengthening public health institutions and the workforce, expanding local manufacturing of vaccines, diagnostics, and therapeutics, and building partnerships with critical stakeholders within the broader health ecosystem.
This Agreement consolidates the joint work that has yielded several achievements, taking it to the next level now that we have moved from the emergency response to address the challenges the continent still faces holistically and from a longer term- perspective.
Africa CDC and APHF Forge Strategic Partnership to Strengthen Health Systems
Download
*** END ***
Note to the Editors
About the Africa CDC
The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) is a continental autonomous public health agency of the African Union that supports member states in efforts to strengthen health systems and improve surveillance, emergency response, and prevention and control of diseases. Learn more at:
https://africacdc.org
About the Africa Public Health Foundation
The Africa Public Health Foundation exists to forge partnerships and mobilise resources and investments for critical African public health initiatives in support of the Africa CDC and African Union’s New Public Health Order.For more information and to sign up for APHF’s newsletter, please visit
http://www.aphf.africa
.

For Africa CDC

Director of Communication and Public Information
EdwinM@africacdc.org
For Africa Public Health Foundation
Eunice Chege
Communications Lead
echege@aphf.africa

Joint Statement on the Africa CDC and United States New Joint Action Plan – Africa CDC
Skip to content
Email:
communications@africacdc.org
Search
Search
News
/
Statement
Joint Statement on the Africa CDC and United States New Joint Action Plan
On November 28, on the sidelines of the Third International Conference on Public Health in Africa in Lusaka, Zambia, the frica Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) and the U.S. government announced a Joint Action Plan to advance a shared vision to strengthen public health systems and deliver improved health outcomes in Africa.
The Joint Action Plan outlines key activities between the Africa CDC and U.S. government to achieve the objectives identified in the Memorandum of Cooperation to Promote Public Health Partnership, signed by African Union Commission Chairperson Moussa Faki and Secretary of State Antony Blinken in March 2022.
The Joint Action Plan represents a significant step toward stronger and deeper Africa CDC -U.S. collaboration, building on both Africa CDC and U.S. health investments and partnerships across Africa. It will facilitate institutional strengthening, expert exchanges, and knowledge-sharing in support of the African Union’s Agenda 2063 and the Africa CDC Strategic Plan 2023-2027. Additionally, it will promote integrated health systems, strengthen public health emergency response capacity, enhance clinical and laboratory systems, and expand innovation and local manufacturing of health products.
The Africa CDC and U.S. government intend to convene regular meetings of technical experts in Addis Ababa and Washington to operationalize, review, and update this Plan to support shared public health needs and global health security requirements.
28 November 2023

Emergency Response and Preparedness

Africa CDC and France sign Memorandum Of Understanding to Strengthen Public Health Systems in Africa – Africa CDC
Skip to content
Email:
communications@africacdc.org
Search
Search
News
/
Press Releases
Africa CDC and France sign Memorandum Of Understanding to Strengthen Public Health Systems in Africa
11 September 2023, Addis Ababa
– The Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC) and the government of France signed a memorandum of understanding (MoU) today to strengthen their cooperation in public health. The MoU was signed by H.E Dr. Jean Kaseya, Director-General of Africa CDC, and Rémi Maréchaux, Ambassador of France to Ethiopia, at a ceremony held at the Africa CDC Secretariat Offices in Addis Ababa.
The MoU aims to strengthen Africa CDC’s efforts to build more robust public health systems and improve health security across the continent. Key areas of collaboration under the MoU include strengthening Africa CDC’s capacity; supporting the development of national public health institutes; enhancing disease surveillance and emergency response capacities; promoting local manufacturing of vaccines, diagnostics and therapeutics; supporting workforce training; and fostering research partnerships between French and African institutions.
“The signing of this MoU solidifies our shared vision in nurturing a coordinated global response to global public health challenges. This action-oriented framework aims to advance the New Public Health order, enhance health workforce development, and strengthen public health systems for the benefit of all African citizens,” said H.E Dr. Jean Kaseya at the signing ceremony.
This MoU builds on France’s longstanding support for public health in Africa. France played a leading role in launching the Access to COVID-19 Tools Accelerator and has donated 10 million vaccine doses to the AVAT mechanism and 48 million doses to 40 African states, mainly through the COVAX initiative aimed at equitable access to COVID-19 vaccines. The French Development Agency provided a €50 million line of credit to Afreximbank for the AVAT payment facility, enabling vaccine purchases by Uganda, Burundi, DRC and Egypt. The AFD has committed over €500 million to health programs in Africa through its ” Santé en Commun ” (Health in Common) initiative. France also provides technical expertise to Africa CDC in infection, prevention and control (IPC) and Water, Sanitation and Hygiene (WASH).
France is a major contributor to Team Europe Initiatives that align with Africa CDC’s priorities, like strengthening pharmaceutical manufacturing capacity on the continent with over €70 million mobilized so far. France also supports regional health projects in West and Central Africa that reinforce Africa CDC’s diagnostics, surveillance, and regulation objectives.
The signing of this MoU signals France and Africa CDC’s continued commitment to mutually tackling major public health challenges in the  interest of public health, safety, and security of all African citizens,”
For media inquiries, please contact:
Mikaele THOMAS
Press department at the French Embassy Tél : 01 11 40 00 25 Mél : Mikaele.thomas@diplomatie.gouv.fr
PO Box 1464, Addis-Ababa Yeka   Kebele : 01102, Addis Abeba

About the African Union:
The African Union is a continental body that leads Africa’s development and integration in close collaboration with the 55 Member States, the Regional Economic Communities and African citizens. The AU’s vision is to accelerate progress towards an integrated, prosperous, and inclusive Africa, at peace with itself, playing a dynamic role in the continental and global arena, effectively driven by an accountable, efficient, and responsive Commission. Learn more at: http://www.au.int/en

High-level event kicks off expansion of strategic EU-AU partnership, pledging joint commitments to strengthen Global Health and African Health Sovereignty – Africa CDC
Skip to content
Email:
communications@africacdc.org
Search
Search
News
/
Press Releases
High-level event kicks off expansion of strategic EU-AU partnership, pledging joint commitments to strengthen Global Health and African Health Sovereignty
Brussels, March 19, 2024 –
The African Union Commission (AUC) and the European Union hosted a High-level Conference marking the expansion of the strategic EU-AU health partnership. The AU delegation was led by the AUC, the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention (Africa CDC), and the African Union Development Agency (AUDA-NEPAD). The EU delegation was led by the Belgian Presidency of the European Council and the European Commission.
Building on the health commitments of the 6th EU-AU Summit and outcomes of the Addis Ababa AU-EU High-level dialogue, the AU and EU expanded collaboration in priority areas of common interest in the New Public Health Order and the EU Global Health Strategy, such as strengthening pandemic prevention, preparedness and response, One Health, AMR, digital health, climate and health. This collaboration is a positive example of the AU-EU partnership to support global health in multilateral fora. Enhancing equitable access to safe, qualitive, effective and affordable health services and products and national sovereignty will be key to reach SDG-targets such as achieving Universal Health Coverage. Therefore, it is crucial to support social protection systems which incorporate social health protection, aiming at gradually granting universal health coverage as well as at providing income security in case of sickness. The AU and EU further stressed the importance of the health sector in the creation of jobs and growth. They also expressed their commitment to conclude negotiations on a pandemic agreement and International Health Regulations by the May 2024 World Health Assembly.
Most African countries are struggling to ensure sustainable and equitable access to the health products needed to meet the continent’s priority health needs. At the same time, the EU has expertise in health as well as manufacturing and access, including regulation of health products and has set out clear targets in supporting human development in its international partnerships.
With this High-level conference, the EU engages in continued technical collaboration on health in Africa and investments in strengthening Africa’s health security architecture. The EU’s Global Gateway strategy will be key to deliver on these commitments, notably through Team Europe Initiatives, increasing the resilience of European and African health systems in response to the rapidly shifting health burden, social protection, the impact of climate change and emerging health threats while considering innovative science, sharing of technical expertise and knowledge (as well as multi-stakeholder commitments).
The Belgian Presidency and the European Commission will follow up on the high-level conference in the European Council and in the governing bodies of the EU’s international cooperation instruments, aligned with shared interests and ambitions of European and African partners.
African Union Commissioner for Health, Humanitarian Affairs and Social Development,
H.E. Amb. Minata Samate Cessouma
“
The establishment of the African Medicines Agency (AMA) marks a crucial step forward in safeguarding health security on the continent by ensuring the availability and the accessibility of quality pharmaceutical products. This availability and accessibility facilitate prevention strategies and rapid responses to health emergencies, strengthening regulatory capacities and promoting regional cooperation and harmonisation of standards. By harmonising regulatory processes and promoting access to effectual medical products, the AMA can significantly enhance public health outcomes and promote sustainable development in Africa, as envisioned in the Africa Health Strategy (2016-2030) and the African Union Agenda 2063. AMA is also envisioned to bolster research and development efforts within the continent, fostering innovation and self-reliance in addressing health challenges specific to the continent. Looking to the future, the African Union Commission is enthusiastic about knowledge-sharing between the European Union and Africa to leverage the experience of establishing the European Mediines Agency to chart guidance and regulatory pathways for the development and approval of new manufacturing technologies and processes.
Belgian Minister of Development Cooperation and Major Cities,
H.E. Caroline GENNEZ
“
The EU and Africa express a shared vision of health as the precondition for social development. African countries have extensive experience in the containment of epidemics; European countries have some of the best and most accessible healthcare in the world. Global health is an area in which the EU offers added value as a partner to Africa based on its expertise and experience. Europe bolsters its international partnerships by focusing on its unique selling proposition. Our cooperation on this front will improve health outcomes for countless of people, in Africa and Europe. Our focus will be on building affordable, available and high-quality healthcare systems.
”
European Commissioner for International Partnerships,
H.E. Jutta URPILAINEN
“
Learning the lessons from the COVID-19 pandemic, the AU and the EU are committed to advance health systems and strengthen health capacities globally. This joint commitment was well reflected in the Global Gateway investment package, which we presented at the AU-EU Summit of 2022. We are proud of the results achieved in increasing local manufacturing of medicines and vaccines in Africa, for Africa. Today we launch three major Team Europe Initiatives on health security, digital health and public health institutes, and strengthen cooperation between our institutions. This is another step forward to better confront evolving health challenges and to enhance the resilience of our communities.
”
European Commissioner for Health and Food Safety,
H.E. Stella KYRIAKIDES
“
An ever-closer partnership between the African Union and the European Union is indispensable for public health. We want to work more closely with our African partners on pandemic prevention, preparedness and response, One Health and anti-microbial resistance, as well as the health effects of climate change. These are core objectives for our EU Global Health Strategy and the foundations of our cooperation with the African continent. We are now at a critical stage of the negotiations on the

,
H.E. Stella KYRIAKIDES
“
An ever-closer partnership between the African Union and the European Union is indispensable for public health. We want to work more closely with our African partners on pandemic prevention, preparedness and response, One Health and anti-microbial resistance, as well as the health effects of climate change. These are core objectives for our EU Global Health Strategy and the foundations of our cooperation with the African continent. We are now at a critical stage of the negotiations on the pandemic agreement and the international health regulations, with which we would provide new multilateral solutions to common challenges. The EU is committed to conclude the negotiations by May, a responsibility equally shared by all nations. I am pleased that the African Union and EU are joining voices and taking concrete steps to support global health internationally.
”
Africa CDC Director General,
H.E Dr Jean Kaseya
“As we navigate the complexities of global health, Africa is on the path towards self-sufficiency through equitable access to medical products. Africa’s target of producing 60% of vaccines by 2040 through the Africa CDC underscores our commitment to health sovereignty. Through strategic partnerships like the EU-AU collaboration, we accelerate our capabilities, leveraging expertise and resources to build resilient health systems and strengthen Pandemic preparedness.”
Specific outcomes of the high-level conference include the following concrete engagements:
Working Arrangement between Africa CDC and the European Commission to best implement the expanded strategic AU-EU Health partnership;
The European Commission and the Belgian Presidency announced additional TEI MAV+ funding for the advancement of the African Medicines Agency;
The announcement of procurement commitments by Global Health Initiatives to buy in Africa for Africa;
Three additional Team Europe Initiatives on health were launched: Health Security using a One Health approach, Digital Health, and Public Health Institutes;
The Team Europe Initiative (TEI) on Social Protection was launched;
Work product leads for Team Europe and Team Africa were confirmed;
A new programme ‘SafeBirth Africa’ to support improved access to innovative life-saving commodities for sexual and reproductive health in Africa. The programme will be implemented by Unitaid and the United Nations Population Fund (UNFPA), supported by a financial contribution of €20 million from the EU budget under the Team Europe Initiative on Sexual and Reproductive Health and Rights that was launched in Kigali in December 2022;
An expanded AU-EU High Level Steering Meeting (HLSM) at DG-level will jointly oversee regional heath TEIs.
-END-
